Package riemannKS

Class Riemann

java.lang.Object
riemannKS.Riemann
Direct Known Subclasses:
LeftHandRule, MidpointRule, RandomRule, RightHandRule, SimpsonsRule, TrapezoidRule
public abstract class Riemann
extends java.lang.Object
Riemann Sums: Create an abstract class with three methods and two abstract methods Methods: rs (calculates the riemann sum by adding up all the slices) rsPlot (plots the polynomial and all the rectangles(or other shapes) rsAcc (graphs the accumulation function) Abstract Methods: slice (calculates the area of one slice) slicePlot (plots just one slice)s Rules Used: Left hand rule Right hand rule Trapezoid rule Random rule Midpoint rule Maximum rule Minimum rule Simpson's rule Answer question: Which Riemann Sum rule is the most effective for approximating area? MostEffectiveRule

  • Method Details

    • rs

      public double rs​(org.dalton.polyfun.Polynomial poly, double left, double right, int subintervals)
      This method calculates the Riemann sum by using the slice method from one of the rules. It adds all the slices together to find the final area under the curve.
      Parameters:
      poly - Polynomial that the user entered
      left - This is the x-coordinate of where we want the area to start
      right - This is the x-coordinate of the we want the area to end
      subintervals - This is the number of rectangles/trapezoids that we separate the area under the curve into
      Returns:
      Returns the area under the curve calculated by the Riemann sum

    • rsPlot

      public void rsPlot​(org.opensourcephysics.frames.PlotFrame pframe, org.dalton.polyfun.Polynomial poly, int index, double precision, double left, double right, int subintervals)
      This method plots the polynomial with the rectangles(and other shapes) whose areas are being added together to find the total area under the curve
      Parameters:
      pframe - The frame where the graph will be displayed
      poly - The polynomial that the user inputs
      index -
      precision - Tells the computer how many points to plot in the graph of the polynomial
      left - The x-coordinate of where the area starts
      right - The x-coordinate of where the area ends
      subintervals - Number of sub rectangles(or other shapes) that are drawn in graph

    • rsAcc

      public void rsAcc​(org.opensourcephysics.frames.PlotFrame pframe, org.dalton.polyfun.Polynomial poly, int index, double precision, double base)
      This methods plots the accumulation function
      Parameters:
      pframe - The frame the graph will be displayed on
      poly - The polynomial the user inputs
      index -
      precision - Tells the computer how many points to plot in the function
      base - The base point of the accumulation function (where it starts)

    • slice

      public abstract double slice​(org.dalton.polyfun.Polynomial poly, double sleft, double sright)
      This method finds the area of each slice
      Parameters:
      poly - The polynomial the user inputs
      sleft - The x-coordinate of where the slice starts
      sright - The x-coordinate of where the slice ends
      Returns:
      Returns the area of one slice

    • slicePlot

      public abstract void slicePlot​(org.opensourcephysics.frames.PlotFrame pframe, org.dalton.polyfun.Polynomial poly, double sleft, double sright)
      This method graphs each slice
      Parameters:
      pframe - The plotframe that the slice will be displayed on
      poly - The polynomial the user inputs
      sleft - The x-coordinate of where the slice starts
      sright - The x-coordinate of where the slice ends
